msDesc.head: Letter from Mary Russell Mitford to George Mitford, 1823 April 3.

support.p: One quarto sheet of paper folded in half to form two octavo pages, which comprise pages 1-4 of the letter. The fourth page exposes the address with some of Mitford's mother's writing at the top of the page. The third page has a slight rip where the wax seal was attached. Also, beneath the address to George Mitford is another address to a Miss Foote, an actress in Mitford's play Julian.

Address leaf bearing the following postmarks: 1) black circular Mileage stampReading
AP 23
1823
2) Red double-circle duty stamp B
23 APR 23
1823
A large 7 denoting a fee for a single-sheet letter has been written in black ink by the postal service across the address leaf.

handNotes.handNote: Mary Russell begins her own quick note to George Mitford follwing the content of her daughter's letter. The note is a quick one and extends to page 4 of the letter--on the same side as the same page used to address the letter. Mary Russell's note is particularly concerned about George Mitford's health and his recovery from a cold.

Red crayon or thick red pencil. Probably a different hand from Mitford's that marks many of her letters, sometimes drawing diagonal lines across pages, and sometimes writing words overtop and perpendicularly across Mitford's writing. On this letter, two red diagonal lines are drawn one at the top left and the other at middle-right of the page. On page 3, there is a red crayon mark across the page from the top left corner to the bottom right. Also on page three, lines 9 through 14 are underlined. of the letter, there is a faint red line that is somewhat closer to vertical than diagonal drawn from the middle-right of the page down and to the left to the bottom of the page.
On page 3, there is a rip where the wax seal once help the letter together. This manifests as a rip through Ms. Mary Russell Mitford's signature.
On page 4 there is another address to Miss Foote at 34 Keppele Lane in Russell Square. She was an actress who originated in the breeches role of Alfonso in Mitford's play, Julian.
The word written at the bottom left hand corner of the address leaf to George Mitford Engle

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

name.placeName:
Old Betty's Chop House
According to Imperial London by Arthur Henry Beavan, Old Betty's Chop House was a tavern along the Strand. This tavern was close to the theatres at Covent Garden and Drury Lane

div.p:
Mr. Talfourd's answer is come--He says that we are -- bound in honor & and not to take the Play away from one house and give it to another--that we can not answer it to ourselves or the Publisher--un--less some very outrageous conduct on the part of the Committee or Mr. Kemble (which certainly in spite of our vexations have not occurred & I hope will not occur) should afford a sufficient & valid season. This is final--I only wish it had arrived two days ago --I have also a letter from Mr. Hamilton, backing out of the message which he certainly delivered to me the next season--I have no doubt in spite of this letter from the few words that passed between Mr. Elliston & Mr. Macready, that the Play would be brought out at Drury Lane if we liked-- but after what Mr. Talfourd has said it would be much better not to think of it--Indeed it is impossible to think of it, for I am sure he would feel himself offended & implicated if we did-- In my own part, I am heartily glad not to have again to encounter this terrible enmity & malignity of Magazines & newspapers--My play--If we have courage & to another, have no name, no woman to attack. I am sure thatThe London Magazine must be very mad indeed,for Miss Andrews requesting her to sent it to me by the Postman this morning, has not sent it Here Mitford's premonistions are correct. In the particular edition of The London Magazine she speaks of, the critic eviscerates the performance of Mr. Marcready, while admiring the work of Mitford's writing in it of itself. Can you at all guess who wrote it? Mr. Procter used to
write the dramatic article in that magazine--but we must not suspect him--even though I know how Mr. Kemble conversation suspecting him & Mr. Macreadythat he has joined managerial faction.--well we must endure it as we may. What you say of Mr. Macready's indisposition grieves me very much I hope if he be not quite removed that he will not think of going through the terrible fatigue of acting Julian to night. Have you given him my letter? I hope not--if you had any previous conversation withMr. Hamiltonyou would not--if you have not bring it back to me.--if you have I shall write a tomorrow--when I shall probably hear whether you have met. Mr. Talfourd advises that Forscari be left for the present at Convent Garden & I agree that it shall--but not to be acted with Mr. Macready for the Doge--never that--he will rely on my on that point I know.--Pray ascertain whether the dedication copy has been sent to him & whether the copies have been sent to the theatre, for all the Performers, the lady & gentle--man who spoke the Prologue & Epilogue--The Commitee --all with the Author's compliments & thanks--I beg you, wile also send one to Miss Howell-->at I. Sheppherd's Esquire Hampstead Heath--one to Mr. Mar--& one to Miss Booth & another to Mrs. RowdenthroughMr. Jones if he will take charge of them to Paris--And pray try to find out who wrote the Article in London--Mr. Southern, at the Hofland's is likely to know--you will make my kindest
regards there of notif you are in that neighborhood call & ask after dearMiss Porden I hope your cold is better--my cough is going fast Dearmama is better too--& everything else is well I have just found out what killed my geraniums They had not been watered I am since past them away till they come back again & then the water ran through the cracked earth as hard as a rock & did not good--I have been working at them all morning poor things.--We have not been the or any one but Miss Brooke who is gone to this morning. Pray do not forget to bring a pot of the white paint without smell & another of black would really write another play to get this room made decent without offense to Mama. God bless you my own dearest Father--
div.closer:
Ever most fondly your's
MR M
To George Mitford EsqreOld Betty's Chop HouseNo. 415 StrandLondon

postscript.p: --Miss Barnes says she wrote to me by return of post--so that she must have been lost--or perhaps misoriented for she is very abstract. She talks of being back in a fortnight but not this way--& wants me to secure her a box for them.--as if I ever dared look forward in that way. God bless you.

The following enlightened Epistle came from Winchester by way ofColeythis morning. My dear friend on the receipt of your newspaper I immediately wrote to you of any delight at the successful result of Julian, which I trust reached its destination. This I mention because out servant Boy might as we suppose have negelcted to put the letter in the Post. I have only to repeat out congratulation, many thanks for the Publication.
Is there a prospect of seeing you. Our best love to all

Ever yours in Haste John Woodburn Winchester March 29th I am rejoiced my dear Husbandto find your cold was better you had a beautiful day for your Journey I can
We shall send inHenryin the morning for the Parcel by the Regulator. Us you may be certain we shall very axious to get it. God bless you ever & ever
I cannot see most truly yours
Mary Mitford
